Award.AwardTitle: Future Changes in the Seasonal Cycle: Mechanisms and Implications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to examine the delay in the seasonal cycle which is commonly found in climate model simulations of anthropogenic global warming. The principal investigators have shown that the seasonal cycles of temperature and precipitation are delayed by a few days at the end of the 21st century compared to the end of the 20th century in climate change simulations. The delay in precipitation means that the onset of the rainy season is delayed in some tropical and subtropical regions. In the Sahel, along the southern margin of the Sahara, the onset is delayed more than the termination resulting in a shorter rainy season in global warming simulations. Similar shortening has been shown in other regions including Central America and the Caribbean in the same global warming simulations. There is also some evidence that the shortening of the Sahel rainly season has occurred in the real world as well as model simulations. The research is organized around three questions: 1) Are the model simulations trustworthy? 2) What is the cause of the delays in the seasonal cycles of temperature and precipitation, and to what extent are they related to each other? 3) What is the reason for the difference between the delays in onset and termination dates of the rainy seasons in the Sahel and other regions? For the temperature annual cycle, one hypothesis is that the delay is due to the loss of sea ice in a warmer climate, which would cause a delay in the seasonal warming of the ocean at high latitudes as sunlight would warm the full surface layer of the ocean rather than the thin surface of snow-covered sea ice. Mechanisms by which delayed warming at high latitudes could be communicated to the tropics will also be considered. For the delay of the rainy season onset, one hypothesis is that global warming has a stabilizing effect on the atmosphere, so that more moisture has to build up in the lower atmosphere in order for rain-bearing convective systems to initiate.

The examination of delays in precipitation and temperature will have practical value by adding to our understanding of the possible consequences of global warming. Changes in the timing and duration of rainy seasons will have impacts on societies and ecosystems worldwide. Since the delays are robust, occurring to some extent in all climate models, the delay could serve as an important test of the credibility of model projections of future global warming. In addition, a better understanding of the underlying mechanisms of the delay could serve to improve our understanding of other potential consequences of global warming. This grant will follow NSF's mandate to incorporate educational opportunities into scientific research by funding a graduate student, who will work on the project while completing an advanced degree in clime science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to understand the mechanisms by which increases in greenhouse gases will change the seasonality of rainfall in monsoon regions. The computer models that are used to simulate how climate will change in the coming decades indicate that the dry season of most monsoon regions will become longer and that the end of the rainy season will intensity. We describe these changes as a delay and an amplification of the seasonal cycle of rainfall. These changes are simulated by the vast majority of the models in the CMIP3 and CMIP6 archives—the two generations of model ensembles that were at the basis of the United Nations Intergovernmen- tal Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) fourth and fifth assessment reports. Yet, there is enough discrepancy across the models that further analysis is warranted, especially given the shortcoming of coarse-resolution models in simulating tropical rainfall. In particular it is important to assess whether the rainfall changes are a necessary consequence of robust changes in the temperature and circulation of the atmosphere.

This project was carried out with the participation of a brilliant graduate student, John Dwyer. The training of this young scientist has been the best outcome of this project. John’s thesis won him the Simon prize for most outstanding dissertation in the Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics Department of Columbia University. The training received during this project secured him a prestigious NSF postdoctoral fellowship that took him to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. At the core of John PhD thesis are both the clever diagnostic analysis of the CMIP3 and CMIP5 simulations and the design, execution, and interpretation of ad-hoc idealized simulations.

Given that the sea surface temperature (SST) of the global oceans is known to greatly influence tropical precipitation, during the first half of this project our focus was on the mechanisms re- sponsible for the seasonality changes in the global SST. By looking jointly at phase and amplitude changes, and by employing a simple energy balance model, we discerned the different mechanisms operating in the high latitudes (where sea ice loss induces changes in the effective heat capacity of the surface layer) and in the tropics (where anomalies in the seasonality of wind and surface heat fluxes drive the SST changes).

Subsequently, we focused on the origin of the precipitation changes. The moisture budget of the CMIP5 simulations indicated that some of the rainfall changes could be explained by changes in atmospheric humidity, while others were a consequence of changes in the large scale circulation. A series of idealized simulations, designed and carried out using the NCAR climate model, further showed that delays in the seasonal march of the zonal mean rainfall can be a consequence of annual mean warming alone, without having to invoke seasonal changes in the forcing. This is an important result, since the annual mean warming is the most robust and certain aspect of climate change; anything that follows directly from that is more trustworthy than anything else the models do. Understanding what hydroclimatic changes are due to warming and by what mechanisms they occur are key steps towards identifying what upcoming changes are beyond doubt, and what changes instead depend on subtleties in the model response, and are therefore more uncertain.
